attributes.title: Backing Up, Not Backing Down: The Effects of Policy Substitution on Audience Costs

q1.value: Backing Up, Not Backing Down: The Effects of Policy Substitution on Audience Costs

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: This registration describes the survey instruments, planned analysis, and expected findings for the fielding of a second set of experiments conducted as part of a broader project that examines the audience costs that constituents dole out on leaders for backing-up (i.e. partially reneging) on foreign policy threats. The first fielding of an online survey instrument in December 2016 collected the bulk of data required for the project. This second fielding of two separate online survey experiments - which are covered by this registration - is designed to provide additional data that will allow for more nuanced analysis of the mechanisms underlying audience cost theory. I also include a description of planned analysis and expected findings for additional analysis I intend to perform on the data collected during the main experiment.

q16.value: Experiment 1: Perceptions Among Threat Recipients: Given the findings on consistency and reputation in the main experiment, I expect respondents to view a rival leader who follows through with his threats as more credible than those who back up or back down. To assess this, I compare mean reputation ratings (see Likert scale in attached survey instrument). Specifically, a leader who follows through should be viewed as consistent, should issue threats and promises that believable, and should improve or significantly improve his country’s standing in the world. Further, respondents should believe that a leader who followed through with a threat of ground invasion is more likely to invade another U.S. ally in the future compared to a leader who backs up on a threat. Leaders who back up to airstrikes should be seen as more credible than those who back up to sanctions. Experiment 2: Perceptions Among Threat Senders (Belligerence Costs/Backing In Inconsistency Costs) One goal of the experiment is to assess whether certain actions generate higher (lower) belligerence (inconsistency) costs than others and to assess whether certain segments of the population levy higher (lower) belligerence (inconsistency) costs than others. To do this, I calculate mean approval ratings of the leader in each of the experimental conditions. Based on the theory of belligerence costs put forth by Kertzer and Brutger (2016), I expect that in the full sample, belligerence costs will be higher for airstrikes than for sanctions. These higher belligerence costs will manifest in the form of lower mean approval ratings for the leader. I will then examine whether hawks or doves (as measured by a question on preferences toward intervention) levy higher belligerence costs. Based on Kertzer and Brutger (2016), I expect self-reported doves to levy higher belligerence costs than their more hawkish counterparts. I also expect self-reported doves to levy lower inconsistency costs than hawks. I must exercise caution in these results, however, because data on preferences toward interventionism are collected post-treatment. To account for this, I examine the distribution of interventionist attitudes across the three treatment groups. If there are no significant differences in the distribution of respondent attitudes toward interventionism across the three groups, I can have greater confidence that interventionism is not driven by exposure to treatments. The experiment also allows me to test the inconsistency costs of “backing in” to a conflict Levy et al (2015). In other words, the President pledges to stay out of a conflict, but then “backs in” by taking some form of military action. Unlike Levy et al who – like most scholars studying audience cost – treat backing in dichotomously, the experiment varies the degree to which the leader backs in (specifically, sanctions, air strikes, and a ground invasion). The primary outcome of interest is mean approval level, and I examine difference in means across the entire sample. I expect the audience costs for backing in to be highest for a ground invasion, followed by sanctions, then airstrikes, and the lowest for staying out. I also examine heterogeneous treatment effects by interacting treatment with a self-reported measure of interventionism. I expect less interventionist respondents to levy audience costs than hawkish respondents. In line with Levy et al (2015), I expect the costs for “backing in” to be lower than those for backing out (Levy et al 2015, 996). I also ask respondents to rate the consistence of the President’s handling of the situation with his initial statement. In line with the findings from the main experiment, I expect that staying out will have the highest mean consistence, followed by sanctions, airstrikes, and a ground invasion (lowest mean consistence rating). Additional Analysis of Data Collected During First Fielding of Main Survey: I intend to conduct additional analysis with data conducted in December 2016 (See attached draft article manuscript). Specifically, I intend to better explain why the audience costs for backing-up to airstrikes are not significantly different from backing up to sanctions. Given the manuscript’s central argument that policy substitution can reduce audience costs by allowing leaders to back up to less inconsistent alternatives (rather than reneging completely and doing nothing at all), it is surprising that there is no significant difference in audience costs between the two backed up conditions (although there are significant differences in audience costs between the follow through, back up, and back down conditions). A closer examination of belligerence costs may explain why there are similar audience costs for the two backed up conditions. In short, since audience costs are the sum of belligerence and inconsistency components, it is possible that some actions generate high belligerence costs and low inconsistency costs while others generate low belligerence costs and high inconsistency costs. Thus, the sum of these data may balance out. Specifically, on average, sanctions may lead to low belligerence costs and high inconsistency costs (if the initial threat is to invade), while airstrikes may generate high belligerence costs and low inconsistency costs. To more closely examine this, I will first examine the distribution of interventionist attitudes across all of the experimental groups. If there are no significant differences between groups, I can have greater confidence that reported preferences toward intervention are not caused by treatment. I will then re-assess the effects of interventionist attitudes on audience costs for the backed-up conditions. Using the approach defined in Kertzer and Brutger (2016), I will disaggregate audience costs into belligerence costs and inconsistency costs. The belligerence costs should all be equal (given that there is no variation in the threat of ground invasion across the various treatment conditions), but inconsistency costs vary (with the highest inconsistency costs for backing down and the lowest for following through). However, I draw from the findings in Experiment 3 (above) to build upon the conception of belligerence costs by introducing variation in the type of threat that was initially issued (i.e. either sanctions or airstrikes) to demonstrate that belligerence costs for backing up to sanctions are lower than those for backing up to airstrikes. This “equalizing” effect of summing low (high) belligerence costs with high (low) inconsistency costs may help to better explain the lack of variation in the overall audience costs for the two backed-up conditions.

q17.value: Experiment 1: Perceptions Among Recipients The first experiment is fielded on a sample of 400 respondents recruited using Amazon Mechanical Turk. The experiment allows me examine how respondents on the receiving end of a threat assess an adversary’s reputation after the adversary either backs down or backs up on a threat. Current experimental research on audience costs examines respondents on the “sending” side of a threat, and uses these data to infer how an adversary views the credibility of the sending state’s future threats and promises. In contrast, my experiment puts respondents on the receiving end of a threat and exposes them to a situation where an adversary threatens to invade a U.S. ally if the U.S. does not close its military bases in the allied country. Qualtrics then randomly assigns respondents into one of four treatment groups that varies the action the adversary country takes: invades, launches airstrikes, enacts economic sanctions, or takes no action. I control for outcomes by telling respondents that “No Americans were harmed by the rival country’s actions.” Respondents are then presented with 13 multiple-choice questions that ask respondents to rate the consistency of the rival leader’s actions (consistency between words and deeds), and to rate the reputational effects of the rival leader’s actions on his and his country’s reputations. The survey instrument accomplishes the latter by asking three questions: 1) Based solely on the rival leader’s actions, how likely is it that the United States will believe threats and promises made by the foreign leader in the future?; 2)How much did the rival leader’s handling of the situation hurt or improve the reputation of his country in the world?; and 3) I pose an explicit scenario: “Several months later, the rival leader threatens to invade another U.S. ally. How likely is it that the rival leader will invade the U.S. ally? Experiment 2: Belligerence Costs/Backing In I field a second experiment on a sample of 800 respondents recruited using Amazon MechanicalTurk. The experiment allows me to examine 1) the disaggregated belligerence and audience costs of various “backed-up” actions and 2) the audience costs of “backing in” – but incrementally – to a conflict after pledging to stay out. The experimental design here draws heavily from 1) the design used in Kertzer and Brutger (2016) to create treatment conditions that allow me to disaggregate audience costs into inconsistency and belligerence cost components and 2) the design used in Levy et al (2015) to study the costs of backing into a conflict. I create eight experimental conditions that vary both the level of ‘belligerence’ and consistency. One on dimension, I vary the type of action the leader pledges/threatens (stay out, air strikes, sanctions). On the other, I vary whether the leader follows through, backs down, or backs in. Qualtrics randomly assigns respondents into one of these eight experimental conditions. Respondents are then presented with 15 multiple-choice questions that, among other questions, ask them to rate the President’s handling of the situation, the President’s competence, and the consistency of the actions. Respondents are also asked to provide demographic information (See attached survey instrument). Respondents are paid 20-cents for completing the survey, which should take approximately five minutes.

attributes.title: Bureaucratic Organization and Service Provision: Field Experimental Evidence from Colombia

q1.value: Bureaucratic Organization and Service Provision: Field Experimental Evidence from Colombia

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: A substantial literature in political economy seeks to explain inequality in access to public goods and services. However, bureaucrats are typically absent or otherwise assumed to be non-strategic actors. Nevertheless, the typical rationale for bureaucrats as “producers of public goods” challenges these assumptions. As the producers and ultimate distributors of public goods and services, I argue that bureaucrats’ role in the distribution of public goods and services should be conceptualized along two dimensions: efficiency and bias. In consultation with three national government agencies in Colombia, I conduct a nationwide factorial audit experiment that measures both efficiency and bias in the administration of two large national social welfare programs. Combined with administrative data on individual bureaucrats, local bureaucracies, and relevant political principals, I measure variation in bureaucrats’ actions as a function of the political and organizational environment into which they are embedded.

q16.value: I hypothesize that there exists variation in both efficiency (time of audit in the day and difficulty of the request) and bias (class, regional origin, and migrant status) in the administration of these social services. I further hypothesize that the magnitude of these effects is conditional on characteristics of de-facto bureaucratic organization at the municipal level.

q17.value: I use a nationwide audit experiment to identify variation in both bias and efficiency in public service provision. I then use original micro-level data to operationalize features of municipal bureaucracies in Colombia in order to estimate conditional effects on bias and efficiency.

However, bureaucrats are typically absent or otherwise assumed to be non-strategic actors. Nevertheless, the typical rationale for bureaucrats as “producers of public goods” challenges these assumptions. As the producers and ultimate distributors of public goods and services, I argue that bureaucrats’ role in the distribution of public goods and services should be conceptualized along two dimensions: efficiency and bias. In consultation with three national government agencies in Colombia, I conduct a nationwide factorial audit experiment that measures both efficiency and bias in the administration of two large national social welfare programs. Combined with administrative data on individual bureaucrats, local bureaucracies, and relevant political principals, I measure variation in bureaucrats’ actions as a function of the political and organizational environment into which they are embedded.
registration_responses.q16: I hypothesize that there exists variation in both efficiency (time of audit in the day and difficulty of the request) and bias (class, regional origin, and migrant status) in the administration of these social services. I further hypothesize that the magnitude of these effects is conditional on characteristics of de-facto bureaucratic organization at the municipal level.
registration_responses.q17: I use a nationwide audit experiment to identify variation in both bias and efficiency in public service provision. I then use original micro-level data to operationalize features of municipal bureaucracies in Colombia in order to estimate conditional effects on bias and efficiency.

attributes.title: Affective Response to Hypothetical and Historical Territorial Threats in International Relations: An online experiment conducted in Australia

q1.value: Affective Response to Hypothetical and Historical Territorial Threats in International Relations: An online experiment conducted in Australia

q5.value: Goldsmith acknowledges support for this research from the Australian Research Council under a Future Fellowship (FT140100763).

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Are mass publics more readily mobilized to support territorial conflicts due to an innate emotional resonance for territorial threats that is the product of human evolution? Can this help explain the special role of territory in international relations? Territorial disagreements between states have been shown to: more frequently lead to militarized conflict than other contentious issues, be more likely to escalate to war, be harder to resolve, and be more likely to lead to enduring international rivalries. Theoretical explanations for these observed patterns have tended to focus on the economic, ethnic or strategic value of the territory for states or citizens, or the salience of territorial issues for elites. These explanations tend to be rationalist, sometimes assuming but rarely investigating an “intangible” value for territory in addition to a material or military value. This sits uneasily with the assertion that humans, like other territorial animals, have an instinctive value for territory that is the product of evolution, that “follows a strategic logic, but one calibrated to cost-benefit ratios that prevailed in our evolutionary past, not those of the present” (Johnson and Toft 2013, 35). Indeed, there is evidence that interstate conflicts over territory with intangible value tend to be the most severe (Hensel and Mitchell 2005), suggesting a large role for non-rational factors. We take a step towards clarifying one possible non-rationalist causal mechanism for territorial conflict, focusing on involuntary emotional reactions. In non-human social animals, territorial conflict has been shown to be associated with cooperative and other altruistic behaviors towards other in-group individuals, and individuals’ roles in territorial defense are often gender-specific. In a pre-registered randomized survey experiment, we test whether a similar pattern is exhibited among Australians who are exposed to information about a territorial threat. We expect to find (as we did in a pre-registered pilot study) that territorial threat elicits cooperativeness among white men born in Australia, and among women of that background it reduces negative affect while increasing generosity through actual charitable donations. Drawing on the evolutionary biology literature, we tie these patterns to an instinctive emotional response to territorial threat that has evolved to help overcome in-group collective action problems for territorial defense. In modern societies, this may create an incentive for political leaders to mobilize publics on territorial issues, because they can strike a deep and unifying emotional chord within citizens. Such a pattern would make territorial conflict rational from the point of view of a power-seeking elite, but not necessarily in terms of the interests of states or their citizens.

q16.value: H1a. There will be an affective response to territorial threats that is distinct from the non-territorial threat condition. H1b. The affective response to territorial threats will be strongest for self-identified whites born in Australia. H2a. The affective response to territorial threats will be distinct for men and women. H2b. Men will exhibit more cooperativeness on the Affect Grid when exposed to the territorial threat treatment. H2c. Women will exhibit less negative emotions on the PANAS when exposed to the territorial threat treatment. H2d. Women will exhibit more generosity in the form of making donations to charity with their incentive payment when exposed to the territorial threat treatment. H3. Treatment effects will be enhanced when human-body-metaphor language is included in the territorial threat treatment. H4. Treatment effects will be enhanced when the true historical case of the bombing of Darwin is used rather than the hypothetical scenarios. The survey also includes a number of questions regarding political attitudes and policy preferences. Unlike our specific hypotheses regarding affective responses to the treatments, these questions are included for exploratory analysis and theory building, but not for hypothesis testing.

q17.value: The treatments are constructed from real-world political rhetoric, news reports, and historical facts from the 1940s, describing the bombing of Darwin by Japan during World War II, as well as hypothetical scenarios designed to parallel these events but not be identifiable as a real historical event. The text will be altered to emphasize no threat, threat, and high threat, and to emphasize non-territorial versus territorial threats. An additional treatment will emphasize territorial threat and use adjectives that treat he human body as a methaphor for the state. To measure affective response, we employ the widely used Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS) originally developed by Watson, Clark, and Tellegen (1988), as well as three Self-Assessment Manikins, and two “Affect grids”. There will also be a control group receiving no text to read. Our hypotheses will be tested for each treatment against the blank control, and for the non-territorial versus territorial treatments. The hypotheses will be tested with statistical tools including difference of means, ANOVA, and regressions.

q24.value: Australian National University Human Ethics Protocol 2017/735

registration_responses.q5: Goldsmith acknowledges support for this research from the Australian Research Council under a Future Fellowship (FT140100763).

There will also be a control group receiving no text to read. Our hypotheses will be tested for each treatment against the blank control, and for the non-territorial versus territorial treatments. The hypotheses will be tested with statistical tools including difference of means, ANOVA, and regressions.
registration_responses.q24: Australian National University Human Ethics Protocol 2017/735

attributes.title: Collaborative Governance Designs, Value-based Conflicts, and Public Perceived Legitimacy

q1.value: Collaborative Governance Designs, Value-based Conflicts, and Public Perceived Legitimacy

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: The quest to enhance legitimacy is one of the strongest drivers for collaborative governance (CG), which is a new trend in policy process engaging people across boundaries of the public, private and civic spheres. Advocates believe CG enjoys higher legitimacy by promoting various public values, including efficiency, representation, empowerment, and so on. However, numerous public values, which may be equally fundamental yet incompatible with each other, exist in reality. Value-based conflicts force CG conveners make trade-off between alternative CG arrangements, which reflect conflicting principles. Such trade-off faced by CG conveners threaten the assumed causality between CG and legitimacy. To make things more complicated, people’s initial position towards a political issue, including their perceived legitimacy towards certain policy process, may fail to remain stable when they are exposed to competing interpretations (Jackman & Sniderman, 2006). In this way, it will not only be important to examine how CG arrangements impact public perceived legitimacy, but more attention should also be paid on how competing CG designs, with conflicting public values, change people’s initial position. All the challenges mentioned above show the complex dynamics between alternative CG designs, the underlying value conflicts, and public perceived legitimacy. This research plan to use survey experiment to address the following questions. 1. How do institutional designs of collaborative governance (CG) influence citizens’ perceived legitimacy towards such CG arrangement? 2. How do citizens adjust their perceived legitimacy when the initial CG arrangement is challenged by competing designs with conflicting public values? 3. How do citizen’s value preferences influence the relationship between CG designs and the perceived legitimacy from the public?

q16.value: 1. Institutional designs in participant selection, in collaborative dynamics, and in decision making will all influence citizen’s perceived legitimacy towards certain CG arrangement. 2. However, citizens’ initial perception of legitimacy hardly remains stable when they are later exposed to competing CG designs which reflect conflicting public values from the initial ones. 3. Due to the trend of New Governance which embodies “democratic ethos” in the US, citizens are more likely to decrease their perceived legitimacy if they are initially presented with CG designs (Design A) reflecting traditional “bureaucratic ethos” and are later exposed to competing designs (Design B) reflecting “democratic ethos”, compared with citizens who are first presented with design A and are later exposed to design B. 4. Citizens’ value preferences moderate the causal relationship between CG arrangements and their perceived legitimacy.

q17.value: This research will focus on a specific group of citizens in the US, which are college students who have the US citizenship. One reason to focus on college students is that, perceived legitimacy should be examined within certain socially constructed system of norms and cultures (Suchman, 1995). However, even for people who all live in the US, the perception of legitimacy may differ a lot, as these individuals were likely to be exposed to various cultures and norms during their developmental-age (Booth, etc., 2017). Considering the complexity of perceived legitimacy, we believe it is reasonable to focus on one of the specific groups of US citizens, the college students in this research, who are in similar birth cohorts and share similar educational backgrounds. Another reason is that college students are regarded as the group of people who are most likely to participate in protests against the authority (Van Dyke 2003). In this way, it will be extremely important to understand how college students regard the legitimacy of certain policy process, as perceived legitimacy guarantees policy compliance and social stability (Birnbaum 2016). Survey experiments will be the major method in this study. The subjects will be randomly divided into two groups. Both groups will be shown three hypothetical cases of collaborative arrangements. Each case respectively describes an arrangement in one of the three CG dimensions (participant selection, collaborative dynamics, decision making). In each of the three cases, the control group will be initially shown with arrangement in the column of Design A in Table 1. For example, in the case of a hypothetical CG arrangement of “Red Lake” Fishery Commission, the control group will be shown with a participant selection design based on willingness. Then we will measure their perceived legitimacy towards such a CG arrangement (first measurement). After that, the control group will be exposed to a counterargument with competing CG arrangement in column Design B, and we will measure their perceived legitimacy towards the initial CG arrangement again after that (second measurement). On the contrary, the experimental group will be first shown with CG arrangement in column Design B before they are exposed to a counterargument with competing arrangement in Design A. We then compare the initial perceived legitimacy in control group and experiment group, and compare the decrease of perceived legitimacy towards initial CG arrangement in both groups during the second measurement of perceived legitimacy. In order to test hypothesis 4, this research also need to measure college students’ preference to various public values. The survey will present a series of public values, including inclusiveness, merits, integrity, efficiency, empowerment and justice. Then the survey will ask them how important they believe these public values are in collaborative governance. The survey will use five point Likert Scale.

attributes.title: Can interest groups really influence a national-wide topic, when it comes out of the blind spot?

q1.value: Can interest groups really influence a national-wide topic, when it comes out of the blind spot?

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Interest groups, therefore, are important players in the making of public policy. But what is the mechanism used to influence officials’ decisions? Do campaign contributions (legal or illegal) the only mechanism to influence politicians? This paper will try to assess a different mechanism. After all, the Brazilian setting provides a unique opportunity to reasons. First of all, in 2015, the Brazilian Supreme Court decided that campaign contributions by companies were illegal. Therefore, companies could not legally contribute to politicians and only individuals (some of them partners of large companies) were allowed to contribute to campaigns. In addition, since 2014 Brazil has been facing one of the largest corruption investigations in history, focusing precisely in the relationship between companies and politicians. This increased the costs both for companies and politicians to engage in bribery or illegal schemes of campaign financing.

q16.value: In this section, I briefly describe the observable implications of the paper: 1. H1: Politicians will comply more when interest groups show a higher level of organization and cohesion; 2. H2: Politicians will comply with interest groups when they are reminded of their financial power

q17.value: To the control group, I am going to send the following message from the executive-director of the NGO: "Dear Deputy, this is Tatiana Ribeiro. I am the executive director of the Movimento Brasil Competitivo. The Chamber of Deputies will vote for the PEC of the Social Security reform. As a citizen, I believe that this is an essential step towards resuming sustainable economic growth. All serious studies show that without reform, the country will not be able to resume growth and generate more jobs. The time to prepare the basis for a better future is now. I invite you to vote in favor of the project. I also draw attention to the fact that the withdrawal of states and municipalities from the project could jeopardize the entire basis of growth. I call special attention to this point, keeping states and municipalities in the project. Here is some of our governance, action and affiliates (http://www.mbc.org.br/portal/quem-somos/)." The treatment group will receive a similar message, with a slightly different beginning: "Dear Deputy, this is Tatiana Ribeiro. I am the executive director of the Movimento Brasil Competitivo, an organization of civil society, which brings together 51 of the largest companies in Brazil, including multinationals. The Chamber of Deputies will vote for the PEC of the Social Security reform. As a citizen, I believe that this is an essential step towards resuming sustainable economic growth. All serious studies show that without reform, the country will not be able to resume growth and generate more jobs. The time to prepare the basis for a better future is now. I invite you to vote in favor of the project. I also draw attention to the fact that the withdrawal of states and municipalities from the project could jeopardize the entire basis of growth. I call special attention to this point, keeping states and municipalities in the project. Here is some of our governance, action and affiliates (http://www.mbc.org.br/portal/quem-somos/)."

attributes.title: Diversity and Judicial Legitimacy in State Courts

q1.value: Diversity and Judicial Legitimacy in State Courts

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Most final legal decisions in civil and criminal cases are made in state trial courts. The National Center for State Courts recognizes that the lack of racial and gender diversity on the bench continues to be a problem in many states, threatening the equality of minorities in the justice system. Many states have established commissions to examine gender and racial bias in the state court system, finding that such bias is common. This project will enhance the social scientific understanding of the relationship between citizens’ expectations of representation and institutional legitimacy within a state judicial context. The first objective of the project is to determine how citizens view representation in a judicial context. The second objective is to determine how views on representation affect an individual’s propensity to ascribe legitimacy to the judiciary. The third objective is to determine the relative impact that descriptive (in terms of race and gender) and substantive representation have on attitudes toward the judiciary. In order to accomplish these objectives, a survey with a series of embedded experiments will be conducted on a cross-section of the U.S. adult population. One experiment focuses on the aggregate numbers of female and African American judges in a state’s trial courts. Respondents are randomly assigned to receive information about either African American judges or female judges in their state. The information varies by the percentage of each group of judges given to the respondent (whether the group in the respondent’s state is higher, lower, or on par with the national average). In the other experiment, respondents are presented with a decision made by a trial judge in their state. The vignette varies by the importance of the political issue involved in the case as well as by the race and gender of the judge deciding the case. A pre-test was conducted in the summer of 2017 to determine certain details of the main survey (the focus of this pre-analysis plan), like the political issues to be involved in the court case for the second experiment. Aside from that, this preregistration and pre-analysis plan is being submitted prior to the main survey being conducted (prior to assignment of treatment).

q16.value: I predict that individuals who are descriptively represented by judges in terms of race and gender will be more likely to view courts favorably by ascribing greater legitimacy to the courts, having greater confidence in the courts and judges, having greater trust in the judicial system, being more likely to believe judges reach decisions in a fair manner, and being more likely to agree with judicial decisions. Additionally, I predict that substantive representation from judges will only matter when individuals care about the political issue being decided by the judge. I also expect that attitudes toward the courts will be moderated by the extent to which individuals expect and value both descriptive and substantive representation from their state’s trial court judges. Lastly, I predict that these expectations will vary by how individuals believe their state selects judges.

q17.value: I will estimate raw differences in reported post-treatment attitudes like judicial legitimacy, confidence, and trust across various demographic groups (African American/white women/men) both within and across treatment groups. Differences in raw means across groups will be reported as well as the estimated treatment effects produced by multivariate regression models that include a standard set of demographic and contextual covariates.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: In this paper we focus on data analysis that explores the relationship between voting behavior, white identity, beliefs about how a candidate will help whites, and political ideology. We utilize a survey to measure both white voters’ extent of linked fate with other whites and also their perception of which presidential candidate will most benefit white voters. Together these two measures provide us with the ability to identify relationship between white linked fate, perception of the political candidates, and voting decisions.

q16.value: H1: Among Democratic voters, the probability of voting for Trump will be higher among those who express White identity and believe that Trump will make things better for whites than will the probability of voting for Trump among other Democrats. [and do not think Clinton will make things better for whites] H2: Among Republican voters, the probability of voting for Clinton will be higher among those who express high White identity and believe that Clinton will make things better for whites than will the probability of voting for Clinton among other Republicans. [and do not think Trump will make things better for whites]. H3: For Republican [Democratic] party identifiers the relationship between white identity and voting for Trump [Clinton] will be stronger for those ideologically distant from Trump [Clinton] than those who are ideologically similar to Trump [Clinton]. H4: For voters who identify with a political party those who report high linked fate and believe that the candidate from their party will make things better for whites will evaluate that candidate more favorably than will other voters in their party, all else equal.

q17.value: The source of our data is the 2016 CCES survey that included a module added by faculty at UC-Riverside. This module includes multiple questions that assess linked fate and its importance among voters. We also use other data from the CCES common content data set.

attributes.title: How does the family react to better jobs opportunities for one member? Evidence from a large-scale public work program in Egypt

q1.value: How does the family react to better jobs opportunities for one member? Evidence from a large-scale public work program in Egypt

q5.value: Many thanks to The Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises Development Agency (MSMEDA) and the World Bank Task Team for making this work possible. Funding from the Jobs MDTF and i2i TF is gratefully acknowledged. Also, thanks to the DIME team in DC and Egypt for their invaluable inputs and hard work in making this study possible.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: PWPs such as Egypt’s ELIIP are widespread in low- and middle-income countries and have been carried out in a variety of settings, including Argentina, Ethiopia, India and South Africa, among others. Together with cash transfer programs constitute the core of many developing countries' social safety nets (Camfield, 2014). Despite the pervasiveness of PWPs across poor and developing countries, rigorous evidence about their impact and effectiveness is still scarce. The empirical literature consists primarily of non-experimental studies evaluating long-running PWPs in India, including the Maharashtra Employment Guarantee Scheme (MEGS) and the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme (MGNREGS). Studies using randomized interventions and in other geographical contexts are still rare. concern with PWPs is that their generalization may have perverse effects or “hidden costs” for participants and non-participants alike. Indeed, some recent papers have found that participation in NREHS in India is linked with lower schooling outcomes and a higher burden of domestic work for school age children. On the other hand, if the spillovers from PWPs are sufficient to increase wages of all low-skill workers in the treatment area (not only program participants), the benefits of the PWP might be severely underestimated by looking only at participants. This paper aims at disentangling the various interactions at the household level that occur after one of its members participates in the PWP. As evidenced by the example above, depending on the specifics of the case, interactions at the household level might counteract as well as increase the potential of the public work programs. Hence the relevance of putting this topic front and center of our investigation.

q16.value: This paper is concerned with two main research questions related to the impact of the ELIIP public work program. The first set of questions is linked to the overall labor market effect of the program: (a) What is the causal impact of participation in the ELIIP PWP on labor market outcomes? a.1. What is the causal effect of ELIIP PWP on individual labor supply at the intensive and extensive margin? a.2. What is the causal effect of participation of ELIIP PWP on net earnings for the participants? (ie, exclusive of foregone earnings) a.3. What is the effect of ELIIP on the earnings of non-participants (spillover effects) (b) What is the causal impact on ELIIP on intra-household labor distribution? b.1. what is the effect of ELIIP on paid work of other household members? b.2. what is the effect of ELIIP on the household work of other household members? b.3. what is the effect of ELIIP on the schooling of children in the household of participants? (c) How is the consumption decision of households modified by ELIIP? c.1. Does the participation in ELIIP translate in more consumption, savings, or both? c.2. How is the structure of consumption modified by ELIIP? c.3. Is there an increase in the consumption of temptation goods?

q17.value: For each research question, we define a main outcome: • a.1 having a job dummy • a.2 total labor earnings of participants • a.3 total labor earnings of non-members • b.1 total labor earnings of other household members • b.2 time devoted to household work or unpaid work of other family members • b.3 number of children engaged in school • c.1 consumption and savings • c.2. repartition of savings between categories • c.3. consumption of temptation goods Due to randomization, the difference between treated and control units indicates the intent-to-treat effect of the program. In order to avoid possible contamination effects between treated and control units within treated villages, our main specification rests on the comparison between participating households, and between households in control villages.

q19.value: The treatment group comprises 1308 individuals, and the control group comprises 1041 individuals, for a total of 2349 observations, over a single round of data collection. These respondents come from a total of 234 villages.

q27.value: The Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises Development Agency (MSMEDA)

registration_responses.q1: How does the family react to better jobs opportunities for one member? Evidence from a large-scale public work program in Egypt

Funding from the Jobs MDTF and i2i TF is gratefully acknowledged. Also, thanks to the DIME team in DC and Egypt for their invaluable inputs and hard work in making this study possible.

(c) How is the consumption decision of households modified by ELIIP? c.1. Does the participation in ELIIP translate in more consumption, savings, or both? c.2. How is the structure of consumption modified by ELIIP? c.3. Is there an increase in the consumption of temptation goods?
registration_responses.q17: For each research question, we define a main outcome: • a.1 having a job dummy • a.2 total labor earnings of participants • a.3 total labor earnings of non-members • b.1 total labor earnings of other household members • b.2 time devoted to household work or unpaid work of other family members • b.3 number of children engaged in school • c.1 consumption and savings • c.2. repartition of savings between categories • c.3. consumption of temptation goods Due to randomization, the difference between treated and control units indicates the intent-to-treat effect of the program. In order to avoid possible contamination effects between treated and control units within treated villages, our main specification rests on the comparison between participating households, and between households in control villages.
registration_responses.q19: The treatment group comprises 1308 individuals, and the control group comprises 1041 individuals, for a total of 2349 observations, over a single round of data collection. These respondents come from a total of 234 villages.
registration_responses.q27: The Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises Development Agency (MSMEDA)
